France, in political crisis, risks having no budget
subhead: With no government and a hard deadline on October 13 for submitting the budget bill to Parliament, every passing day makes it more likely France will enter 2026 without a budget.

headline: AI is already upending the US job market as predictions of a 'jobs apocalypse' multiply
subhead: From PwC to Walmart and Accenture, more and more American companies are citing artificial intelligence to explain hiring slowdowns, targeted layoffs and accelerated reorganizations.

headline: New China reform aims to improve social protection for employees
subhead: Since a new judicial interpretation by the Supreme People's Court came into effect on September 1, employers have been required to pay social security contributions, even if there is no formal contract in place.

headline: Turkish community in northwest Germany tempted by far-right AfD party
subhead: While Turkish immigrants in the Marxloh neighborhood of Duisburg had until now mostly voted for the Social Democratic party (SPD, center-left), they have gradually been drawn to the anti-immigration and conservative rhetoric of the far-right.

headline: Europe faces new challenge as Russian drones breach its airspace
subhead: Despite repeated drone overflights, few European countries have dared to call Russia's hybrid attacks an act of war, wary of alarming the public or provoking escalation.

Trump's ineffective campaign to secure the Nobel Peace Prize
subhead: The American president's aggressive tactics have taken Norwegian experts by surprise. Yet in Oslo, the committee responsible for awarding the prize remains unfazed by attempts at influence, according to its secretary.

headline: Why foreigners love France but struggle with the French
subhead: While France captivates with its culture and lifestyle, the French, frequently caricatured as arrogant and impolite, often have a poor reputation. This ambivalence raises questions about the roots of anti-French sentiment abroad.

headline: France's left more fragmented than ever after Lecornu's resignation
subhead: The Socialists are still looking to present themselves as a fallback option for governing the country, while the radical left La France Insoumise called again for President Emmanuel Macron's departure.
